thread.title: Holiday cabins in Norway - could you get any closer to the water?
thread.title_full: Holiday cabins in Norway - could you get any closer to the water?

title: Holiday cabins in Norway - could you get any closer to the water?
text:
Police investigating death of a man in Kaitaia supermarket carpark Holiday cabins in Norway - could you get any closer to the water? Last updated 10:24, October 22 2015 Siggen Stinessen 
Holiday huts designed by Stinessen Arkitektur - in Sweden 
Holidays in remote locations have become increasingly popular in recent years - here's a resort that makes the most of the elements. 
Celebrated polar explorer Borge Ousland's new adventure and exploration resort is off the coast of Northern Norway, on Manshausen Island, in the Steigen Archipelago. 
The Manshausen Island Resort features a collection of contemporary holiday cabins designed by Stinessen Arkitektur. Most of these are partially cantilevered over the sea, with one is positioned on a rocky outcrop. SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR SIGGEN STINESSEN/STINESSEN ARKITEKTUR Siggen Stinessen 
The huts are cantilevered over the large rocky foreshore. 
The holiday huts are angled to provide privacy for guests. 
The pared-back exteriors feature a mix of glass and larch wood, which will be left to weather naturally to a soft silver grey. 
The huts appear to be perched on the rocks on the coastline. 
Nothing between you and the view - the architecture maximises the sun and the view. 
Full-height glazing enhances the connection with the water. 
Natural wood features throughout the interiors, which have galley-style kitchens. 
Stinessen Arkitektur designed these cantilevered holiday huts at the Manshausen Island Resort in northern Norway. 1 of 8 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
The pared-back architecture allows uninterrupted views of the remote landscape and the elements, which can be severe at times. Clad in larch wood, the cabins will be left to weather to a natural silver grey.
